metadata.description: Scenario-Based Study Companion for GCP Networking Fundamentals - covers VPC networks, subnets, firewall rules, load balancing, Cloud VPN, Cloud Interconnect, Cloud NAT, Cloud DNS, and Private Google Access.

question.title: VPC Network Fundamentals
question.scenario: Your company is starting a new project on Google Cloud and needs to set up isolated network resources for different environments (development, staging, production).
question.question-text: What is the primary characteristic of a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) network in Google Cloud?

choices.choice: A global, private, isolated virtual network that spans all GCP regions
A regional network limited to a single geographic area
A physical network within Google's data centers
A public network shared between multiple GCP customers

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: VPC networks in GCP are global resources, unlike some other cloud providers.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: A Google Cloud VPC is a global, private, isolated virtual network that spans all GCP regions automatically. This means you can have subnets in different regions within the same VPC, enabling global connectivity without additional configuration.

ul.li: VPCs are global; subnets are regional resources.
Resources in different regions within the same VPC can communicate via internal IPs.
Each project starts with a default VPC network that has auto-mode subnets.

question.title: Subnet Modes
question.scenario: You are creating a new VPC network and need to decide how IP address ranges will be allocated across regions.
question.question-text: What is the difference between auto mode and custom mode VPC networks?

choices.choice: Auto mode creates subnets automatically in each region; custom mode requires manual subnet creation
Auto mode is for production; custom mode is for development only
Auto mode uses public IPs; custom mode uses private IPs
Auto mode is free; custom mode has additional charges

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Auto mode VPCs automatically provision subnets; custom mode gives you full control.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Auto mode VPC networks automatically create one subnet per region using predefined IP ranges from 10.128.0.0/9. Custom mode VPCs require you to manually create subnets with IP ranges you specify, providing greater control over IP addressing.

ul.li: Auto mode subnets use 10.128.0.0/9, with /20 ranges per region.
Custom mode is recommended for production to avoid IP conflicts.
You can convert auto mode to custom mode, but not vice versa.

question.title: Subnet IP Ranges
question.scenario: Your network team needs to plan IP address allocation for a new custom mode VPC that will host Kubernetes clusters requiring large IP ranges for pods and services.
question.question-text: What feature allows you to assign additional IP ranges to a subnet beyond the primary range?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Secondary ranges allow multiple IP ranges on a single subnet for different purposes.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Secondary IP ranges (alias IP ranges) allow you to assign additional CIDR blocks to a subnet. These are commonly used with GKE to provide separate IP ranges for pods and services without consuming the primary subnet range.

ul.li: Primary range is used for VM primary internal IPs.
Secondary ranges are used for alias IPs (pods, services in GKE).
VPC-native GKE clusters require secondary ranges for pods and services.

question.title: Firewall Rule Basics
question.scenario: You deployed a web application on a Compute Engine VM but users cannot access it from the internet.
question.question-text: What type of VPC firewall rule is needed to allow incoming traffic to a VM?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Ingress rules control incoming traffic; egress rules control outgoing traffic.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: To allow incoming traffic to a VM, you need an ingress allow rule. Ingress rules filter incoming connections to VMs, while egress rules filter outgoing connections from VMs. By default, ingress is denied and egress is allowed.

ul.li: Default VPC has implied deny all ingress and allow all egress rules.
Firewall rules are stateful: response traffic is automatically allowed.
Rules are evaluated by priority (lower number = higher priority).

question.title: Firewall Rule Targets
question.scenario: You have multiple web servers and database servers in your VPC. You need to create firewall rules that apply only to web servers.
question.question-text: What is the recommended method to target specific VMs with firewall rules?

choices.choice: Use network tags or service accounts
Specify individual IP addresses in each rule
Create separate VPC networks for each server type
Use VM instance names in firewall rules

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Network tags and service accounts provide flexible targeting for firewall rules.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Network tags and service accounts are the recommended ways to target VMs with firewall rules. Tags are user-defined strings attached to VMs, while service accounts provide identity-based targeting. Both allow rules to dynamically apply to new VMs matching the criteria.

ul.li: Service accounts are more secure as they cannot be changed by instance admins.
Network tags can be modified by users with instance admin permissions.
Rules can target all instances, tagged instances, or service account-based instances.

question.title: Firewall Rule Priority
question.scenario: You have two firewall rules: one allows SSH from all sources with priority 1000, and another denies all traffic from a specific IP range with priority 900.
question.question-text: Which rule takes precedence when traffic from the specific IP range attempts SSH access?

choices.choice: The deny rule with priority 900 takes precedence
The allow rule with priority 1000 takes precedence
Both rules are evaluated and the allow wins
The rules cancel each other out

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Lower priority numbers indicate higher precedence in firewall rules.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Firewall rules are evaluated by priority, with lower numbers having higher precedence. The rule with priority 900 (deny) is evaluated before the rule with priority 1000 (allow), so traffic from the specific IP range will be denied.

ul.li: Priority ranges from 0 (highest) to 65535 (lowest).
Default rules have priority 65534-65535.
When priorities match, deny rules take precedence over allow rules.

question.title: Load Balancer Types Overview
question.scenario: Your company needs to distribute incoming web traffic across multiple VM instances in different regions for a globally accessible application.
question.question-text: Which Google Cloud load balancer type is best suited for global HTTP/HTTPS traffic distribution?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Global Application Load Balancer handles HTTP/HTTPS traffic across regions.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: The Global external Application Load Balancer (formerly HTTP(S) Load Balancer) is designed for global HTTP/HTTPS traffic. It provides a single anycast IP, SSL termination, content-based routing, and automatic multi-region failover.

ul.li: Uses Google's global network for optimal routing to nearest healthy backend.
Supports URL maps for content-based routing to different backend services.
Integrates with Cloud CDN for caching and Cloud Armor for security.

question.title: Backend Services
question.scenario: You are configuring an Application Load Balancer and need to define where traffic should be sent based on health checks.
question.question-text: What component of a load balancer defines the group of backends and their health check configuration?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Backend services group backends together and define health checking behavior.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: A backend service defines a group of backends (instance groups or NEGs), health check configuration, session affinity, and load balancing algorithm. Traffic is distributed among healthy backends based on these settings.

ul.li: Backend services support managed instance groups, unmanaged instance groups, and NEGs.
Health checks determine backend availability; unhealthy backends don't receive traffic.
Balancing mode can be based on utilization, rate, or connections.

question.title: URL Maps and Routing
question.scenario: You want to route requests to /api/* to one set of backends and /static/* to another set of backends using the same load balancer.
question.question-text: Which load balancer component enables content-based routing to different backend services?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: URL maps define how requests are routed based on URL paths and hosts.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: URL maps define rules that route requests to different backend services based on URL host and path. They support path matchers, host rules, and default services, enabling sophisticated content-based routing from a single IP.

ul.li: Path matchers define routing based on URL path prefixes or exact matches.
Host rules can route different domains to different backends.
URL maps also support header-based and parameter-based routing.

question.title: Internal Load Balancing
question.scenario: Your application has a frontend tier that needs to communicate with a backend database tier. Both tiers are within the same VPC and should not be exposed to the internet.
question.question-text: Which load balancer type should you use for internal-only traffic within a VPC?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Internal load balancers distribute traffic using private IP addresses within a VPC.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Internal passthrough Network Load Balancer (formerly Internal TCP/UDP Load Balancer) distributes traffic among backends using a private IP address accessible only within your VPC. It's ideal for internal tiers like databases or internal microservices.

ul.li: Internal load balancers are regional resources.
They use Andromeda (Google's SDN) for software-defined load balancing.
Support for TCP, UDP, and other IP protocols (not just HTTP).

question.title: Cloud VPN Overview
question.scenario: Your company needs to establish a secure connection between your on-premises data center and Google Cloud VPC without using dedicated hardware.
question.question-text: What service provides encrypted connectivity between on-premises networks and GCP over the public internet?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud VPN creates IPsec tunnels over the public internet for secure connectivity.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud VPN securely connects your on-premises network to your Google Cloud VPC through an IPsec VPN tunnel over the public internet. Traffic is encrypted by one VPN gateway and decrypted by the other, providing secure communication without dedicated hardware.

ul.li: Supports both Classic VPN (single tunnel) and HA VPN (high availability with two tunnels).
HA VPN provides 99.99% SLA when configured with two tunnels.
Uses IKEv1 or IKEv2 for key exchange and supports various encryption algorithms.

question.title: HA VPN Configuration
question.scenario: Your organization requires a highly available VPN connection with 99.99% uptime SLA between on-premises and Google Cloud.
question.question-text: What is required to achieve the 99.99% SLA with HA VPN?

choices.choice: Configure two VPN tunnels from HA VPN gateway to the peer gateway
Use Classic VPN with a single tunnel
Deploy the VPN gateway in multiple regions

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: HA VPN requires two tunnels for the 99.99% SLA guarantee.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: HA VPN gateways have two interfaces, each with its own external IP. To achieve the 99.99% SLA, you must configure VPN tunnels from both interfaces to your peer VPN gateway, providing redundancy if one tunnel fails.

ul.li: HA VPN supports only dynamic routing with Cloud Router (BGP).
Each interface connects to a different edge availability domain.
Active/active or active/passive configurations are supported based on peer gateway capabilities.

question.title: Cloud Router and BGP
question.scenario: You need dynamic route exchange between your on-premises network and GCP so that new subnets are automatically advertised.
question.question-text: What GCP service enables dynamic routing using BGP for hybrid connectivity?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud Router uses BGP to dynamically exchange routes with peer networks.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Router is a fully distributed, software-defined router that uses BGP to dynamically exchange routes between your VPC and on-premises networks. It automatically learns and advertises routes, eliminating manual route management.

ul.li: Cloud Router is required for HA VPN and recommended for all dynamic routing scenarios.
Supports custom route advertisements to control which routes are shared.
Regional resource that can peer with multiple on-premises routers.

question.title: Cloud Interconnect Options
question.scenario: Your company requires high-bandwidth, low-latency connectivity to Google Cloud that doesn't traverse the public internet.
question.question-text: Which service provides dedicated, private connectivity to Google Cloud with higher bandwidth than VPN?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud Interconnect provides dedicated private connections bypassing the public internet.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Interconnect provides dedicated, private connectivity between on-premises networks and Google Cloud. Dedicated Interconnect offers 10 Gbps or 100 Gbps connections directly to Google. Partner Interconnect provides connectivity through supported service providers for lower bandwidth needs.

ul.li: Dedicated Interconnect requires colocation at a Google edge location.
Partner Interconnect is available through service providers when colocation isn't possible.
Both support VLAN attachments for multiple VPCs and projects.

question.title: Dedicated vs Partner Interconnect
question.scenario: Your company is evaluating Cloud Interconnect options. You are not colocated at a Google edge facility but need more bandwidth than VPN provides.
question.question-text: Which Cloud Interconnect option should you choose when you cannot colocate at a Google edge facility?

choices.choice: Partner Interconnect through a supported service provider

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Partner Interconnect enables connectivity through service providers without colocation.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Partner Interconnect provides connectivity to Google Cloud through supported service providers. This is ideal when your data center isn't colocated at a Google edge facility. Partners handle the physical connection to Google, and you connect to the partner.

ul.li: Partner Interconnect supports 50 Mbps to 50 Gbps depending on provider.
Layer 2 partners provide VLAN tags; Layer 3 partners provide BGP peering.
Partner Interconnect has a 99.9% SLA; Dedicated Interconnect can achieve 99.99% with redundancy.

question.title: VPC Peering
question.scenario: Your organization has two separate GCP projects that need to communicate using internal IP addresses without going through the public internet.
question.question-text: What feature allows two VPC networks to communicate using internal IP addresses?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: VPC Peering connects two VPC networks for internal IP communication.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: VPC Network Peering allows two VPC networks to communicate using internal IP addresses, whether in the same project or different projects/organizations. Traffic stays within Google's network and doesn't traverse the public internet.

ul.li: Peering is non-transitive: if A peers with B and B peers with C, A cannot reach C through B.
Peered networks must have non-overlapping IP ranges.
Each network can have up to 25 peering connections by default.

question.title: Shared VPC
question.scenario: Your organization wants multiple projects to share a common VPC network managed by a central network team while allowing project teams to manage their own resources.
question.question-text: What feature allows multiple projects to share a centrally managed VPC network?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Shared VPC lets service projects use a host project's VPC network.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Shared VPC allows an organization to connect resources from multiple projects to a common VPC network hosted in a host project. The network admin manages the VPC in the host project, while service project teams deploy resources using that shared network.

ul.li: Host project contains the Shared VPC network; service projects attach to it.
Network and security admins manage the Shared VPC; project teams manage their resources.
Supports granular subnet-level permissions for service projects.

question.title: Private Google Access
question.scenario: Your VMs have only internal IP addresses but need to access Google Cloud APIs and services like Cloud Storage.
question.question-text: What feature allows VMs without external IPs to access Google APIs and services?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Private Google Access enables access to Google APIs without external IPs.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Private Google Access allows VMs with only internal IP addresses to reach Google APIs and services (like Cloud Storage, BigQuery, Pub/Sub) without requiring external IP addresses. It's enabled at the subnet level.

ul.li: Private Google Access must be enabled on each subnet where it's needed.
VMs with external IPs can access Google APIs regardless of this setting.
For on-premises access to Google APIs, use Private Service Connect or restricted.googleapis.com.

question.title: Cloud NAT
question.scenario: Your VMs need to download software updates from the internet but should not have external IP addresses for security reasons.
question.question-text: What service provides outbound internet connectivity for VMs without external IP addresses?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud NAT provides outbound NAT for VMs without external IPs.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud NAT (Network Address Translation) allows VMs without external IP addresses to access the internet for outbound connections (like downloading updates). It performs source NAT on outbound traffic while preventing unsolicited inbound connections.

ul.li: Cloud NAT is software-defined, highly available, and scales automatically.
It's configured on Cloud Router and applies to specific subnets or all subnets in a region.
Only provides outbound access; unsolicited inbound traffic is not allowed.

question.title: Cloud DNS Overview
question.scenario: You need to manage DNS records for your domain and ensure high availability and low latency DNS resolution globally.
question.question-text: What Google Cloud service provides managed, authoritative DNS hosting?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud DNS is Google's managed authoritative DNS service.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud DNS is a high-performance, resilient, global DNS service that publishes your domain names to the global DNS using Google's infrastructure. It provides 100% SLA for authoritative name resolution.

ul.li: Supports public zones (internet-facing) and private zones (VPC internal).
Offers DNSSEC for authentication of DNS responses.
Provides anycast name servers for low-latency responses globally.

question.title: Private DNS Zones
question.scenario: You want to create internal DNS names for your VMs that are only resolvable within your VPC network.
question.question-text: What Cloud DNS feature provides DNS resolution only within specified VPC networks?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Private zones provide internal DNS visible only to authorized VPC networks.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Private managed zones in Cloud DNS provide DNS records that are only resolvable from authorized VPC networks. This allows you to create internal DNS names (like db.internal.example.com) that aren't visible on the public internet.

ul.li: Private zones can be attached to multiple VPCs across projects using Shared VPC or DNS peering.
Overlapping zones are resolved by longest suffix matching.
Private zones can override public DNS for split-horizon DNS scenarios.

question.title: DNS Forwarding
question.scenario: Your hybrid environment requires VMs in GCP to resolve DNS names hosted on your on-premises DNS servers.
question.question-text: What Cloud DNS feature forwards DNS queries to on-premises or other DNS servers?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Forwarding zones redirect DNS queries to specified target name servers.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: DNS forwarding zones configure Cloud DNS to forward queries for specific domains to designated target name servers, such as on-premises DNS servers. This enables hybrid DNS resolution where GCP resources can resolve on-premises DNS names.

ul.li: Target servers can be on-premises (via VPN/Interconnect) or external.
Requires Cloud DNS inbound or outbound forwarding configuration.
DNS Server Policy enables inbound forwarding from on-premises to Cloud DNS.

question.title: Cloud CDN Overview
question.scenario: Your web application serves static content to users worldwide and you want to reduce latency and origin server load.
question.question-text: What Google Cloud service caches content at edge locations to reduce latency for users?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud CDN caches content at Google's edge locations globally.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud CDN (Content Delivery Network) uses Google's globally distributed edge points of presence to cache HTTP(S) content close to users. This reduces latency, decreases load on origin servers, and can reduce egress costs.

ul.li: Cloud CDN integrates with Global external Application Load Balancer.
Supports cache invalidation for stale content removal.
Signed URLs and signed cookies provide access control for cached content.

question.title: Cloud Armor Overview
question.scenario: Your public-facing web application needs protection against DDoS attacks and common web vulnerabilities like SQL injection.
question.question-text: What Google Cloud service provides DDoS protection and Web Application Firewall (WAF) capabilities?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud Armor provides DDoS protection and WAF for load-balanced applications.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Armor provides DDoS protection, WAF capabilities, and access control for applications behind Global external Application Load Balancer. It includes preconfigured rules for OWASP Top 10 threats and allows custom rules based on IP, geography, and request attributes.

ul.li: Security policies contain rules that are evaluated in priority order.
Supports adaptive protection using ML to detect and mitigate attacks.
Rate limiting controls traffic volume from specific sources.

question.title: Cloud Armor Security Policies
question.scenario: You need to block traffic from specific countries and rate limit requests to your API endpoints while allowing legitimate traffic.
question.question-text: What component of Cloud Armor defines the rules for allowing or denying traffic?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Security policies contain rules that determine traffic handling.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Armor security policies contain rules that are evaluated in priority order. Each rule has a match condition (IP ranges, geo location, expressions) and an action (allow, deny, throttle, redirect). The first matching rule determines the action.

ul.li: Rules support complex expressions using Common Expression Language (CEL).
Geo-based rules use IP geolocation to identify source countries.
Rate limiting rules can throttle or ban sources exceeding thresholds.

question.title: Identity-Aware Proxy
question.scenario: You want to control access to your internal web applications based on user identity rather than network location.
question.question-text: What Google Cloud service provides context-aware access control for applications without a VPN?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: IAP verifies user identity and context before granting access to applications.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Identity-Aware Proxy (IAP) controls access to cloud applications and VMs based on user identity and context (device, location, etc.) rather than network location. Users are authenticated by Google identity services, enabling BeyondCorp-style zero-trust access.

ul.li: Works with App Engine, Compute Engine, GKE, and on-premises applications.
Integrates with Access Context Manager for context-aware policies.
Supports TCP forwarding for SSH/RDP access without bastion hosts.

question.title: VPC Service Controls
question.scenario: You need to prevent data exfiltration from sensitive Google Cloud services like BigQuery and Cloud Storage, even by authorized users.
question.question-text: What feature creates security perimeters around Google Cloud services to prevent data exfiltration?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: VPC Service Controls create security perimeters around GCP services.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: VPC Service Controls allow you to define security perimeters around Google Cloud resources to prevent data exfiltration. Even with proper IAM permissions, data cannot move outside the perimeter unless explicitly allowed through ingress/egress rules.

ul.li: Perimeters protect BigQuery, Cloud Storage, GKE, and other services.
Access Context Manager defines who/what can cross perimeter boundaries.
Dry-run mode allows testing policies before enforcement.

question.title: Routes and Routing
question.scenario: You need to understand how traffic flows from VMs in your VPC to destinations on the internet and other networks.
question.question-text: What determines the path that network traffic takes from a VM to its destination?

choices.choice: Routes in the VPC routing table

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Routes define the paths for network traffic in a VPC.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Routes define the paths that network packets take from VM instances to destinations. The VPC routing table contains system-generated routes (for subnets and default internet) and custom routes (static or learned via Cloud Router).

ul.li: System routes are created automatically for subnets and default gateway.
Custom static routes can direct traffic to specific next hops.
Dynamic routes are learned from Cloud Router via BGP.

question.title: Custom Static Routes
question.scenario: You need to route traffic destined for a specific IP range through a network virtual appliance (firewall VM) in your VPC.
question.question-text: What type of route should you create to direct traffic through a specific VM instance?

choices.choice: Custom static route with next hop as the VM instance

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Custom static routes specify explicit next hops for traffic.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Custom static routes allow you to define explicit routing paths with various next hop types: VM instances, internal load balancers, VPN tunnels, or internet gateways. This enables traffic steering through virtual appliances like firewalls or NAT instances.

ul.li: Next hop can be instance, internal LB, VPN tunnel, internet gateway, or IP address.
Routes can be scoped to specific VMs using network tags.
More specific routes (longer prefix) take precedence over less specific ones.

question.title: Health Checks
question.scenario: Your load balancer is sending traffic to unhealthy backend instances, causing user errors.
question.question-text: What load balancer component determines whether backend instances can receive traffic?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Health checks probe backends to determine their availability.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Health checks periodically probe backend instances to verify they can receive traffic. Instances failing health checks are marked unhealthy and removed from the load balancing pool until they recover. Health check protocols include HTTP, HTTPS, TCP, SSL, and gRPC.

ul.li: Configure check interval, timeout, healthy/unhealthy thresholds.
Health check probes come from Google's health check IP ranges (130.211.0.0/22, 35.191.0.0/16).
Firewall rules must allow health check traffic to backends.

question.title: SSL/TLS Termination
question.scenario: You want to offload SSL/TLS encryption from your backend servers to reduce their CPU load.
question.question-text: At what point does the Global external Application Load Balancer terminate SSL/TLS connections by default?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Application Load Balancer terminates SSL at the frontend by default.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: The Global external Application Load Balancer terminates SSL/TLS at the load balancer frontend. This offloads encryption processing from backends. Traffic between the load balancer and backends can be HTTP or HTTPS depending on your configuration.

ul.li: Supports Google-managed, self-managed, and customer-managed SSL certificates.
End-to-end encryption is possible by configuring HTTPS to backends.
SSL policies control which TLS versions and cipher suites are allowed.

question.title: Network Endpoint Groups
question.scenario: You want to load balance traffic directly to containers in GKE without going through a NodePort service.
question.question-text: What resource type allows load balancers to target individual pods or containers directly?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: NEGs enable container-native load balancing directly to pods.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Network Endpoint Groups (NEGs) are collections of IP:port endpoints that can represent pods, VMs, or external endpoints. Container-native load balancing uses NEGs to route traffic directly to pods, bypassing the kube-proxy and NodePort, improving performance.

ul.li: Zonal NEGs for GCE VMs and GKE pods.
Internet NEGs for external backends outside GCP.
Serverless NEGs for Cloud Run, App Engine, and Cloud Functions.

question.title: VPN Tunnel Configuration
question.scenario: You are setting up Cloud VPN and need to ensure that traffic for your on-premises network (10.0.0.0/8) routes through the VPN tunnel.
question.question-text: How are routes for on-premises networks typically configured with HA VPN?

choices.choice: Dynamically through BGP sessions with Cloud Router
Manually created as static routes for each tunnel
Automatically detected by the VPN gateway
Configured in the on-premises firewall only

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: HA VPN requires Cloud Router and BGP for dynamic route exchange.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: HA VPN requires dynamic routing through Cloud Router using BGP. Routes for on-premises networks are learned through BGP sessions, and VPC routes are advertised to on-premises. This eliminates manual route management when networks change.

ul.li: Classic VPN supports static routing; HA VPN requires dynamic routing.
BGP ASN must be configured on both Cloud Router and on-premises router.
Custom route advertisements can control which routes are shared.

question.title: Internal IP Addresses
question.scenario: You need a VM's internal IP address to remain the same even if the VM is deleted and recreated.
question.question-text: What type of internal IP address should you reserve for this requirement?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Static internal IPs persist independently of VM lifecycle.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Static internal IP addresses are reserved and persist independently of VM instances. When a VM is deleted, a static IP remains reserved and can be assigned to a new VM. Ephemeral IPs are released when the VM is deleted.

ul.li: Static IPs can be regional (for VMs) or global (for global load balancers).
Reserved IPs incur charges when not attached to a running resource.
Alias IPs are additional IPs assigned to a VM's network interface, not primary IPs.

question.title: External IP Addresses
question.scenario: Your VM needs to be accessible from the internet, but you want the IP address to persist across VM stops and starts.
question.question-text: What type of external IP should you use for a VM that needs a persistent public IP?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Static external IPs remain assigned through VM stop/start cycles.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Static external IP addresses are reserved and remain assigned to a VM even when stopped and started. Ephemeral external IPs may change when a VM is stopped. Static IPs are useful when external systems need to whitelist your VM's IP.

ul.li: Static external IPs can be regional (standard tier) or global (premium tier).
Premium tier uses Google's global network; standard tier uses regional routing.
Unused static external IPs incur charges to encourage efficient usage.

question.title: Hierarchical Firewall Policies
question.scenario: Your organization wants to enforce consistent firewall rules across all projects while allowing project teams some flexibility.
question.question-text: What feature allows you to define firewall rules at the organization or folder level?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Hierarchical policies apply firewall rules across the resource hierarchy.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Hierarchical firewall policies allow you to create and enforce firewall rules at the organization or folder level, providing consistent security across all projects. Rules can allow, deny, or delegate to lower-level policies using goto_next action.

ul.li: Rules are evaluated top-down: organization, folder, VPC network.
goto_next action delegates to the next level in the hierarchy.
Enforces security baselines while allowing project-level customization.

question.title: Managed Instance Groups
question.scenario: You want to automatically scale the number of web server VMs based on traffic load behind a load balancer.
question.question-text: What GCP feature provides auto-scaling and auto-healing for groups of identical VMs?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: MIGs provide automated scaling and healing for VM fleets.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Managed Instance Groups (MIGs) create and manage groups of identical VM instances from an instance template. MIGs support autoscaling based on metrics, autohealing based on health checks, and automated rolling updates.

ul.li: Regional MIGs distribute instances across zones for high availability.
Autoscaler adjusts size based on CPU, LB utilization, or custom metrics.
Autohealer recreates unhealthy instances based on health check results.

question.title: Cloud CDN Cache Modes
question.scenario: You want fine-grained control over which responses are cached by Cloud CDN and for how long.
question.question-text: What determines how Cloud CDN decides whether to cache a response?

choices.choice: Cache mode settings and cache headers from origin
Only the file extension of the request
Time of day the request is made

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cache behavior depends on mode settings and origin response headers.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud CDN caching is controlled by cache mode (CACHE_ALL_STATIC, USE_ORIGIN_HEADERS, FORCE_CACHE_ALL) and cache headers from the origin (Cache-Control, Expires). The cache mode determines how strictly origin headers are followed.

ul.li: CACHE_ALL_STATIC caches common static content types automatically.
USE_ORIGIN_HEADERS requires valid cache headers from origin.
FORCE_CACHE_ALL caches all successful responses regardless of headers.

question.title: VLAN Attachments
question.scenario: You have a Dedicated Interconnect connection and need to connect it to multiple VPC networks in different projects.
question.question-text: What resource connects a Cloud Interconnect connection to a VPC network?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: VLAN attachments connect Interconnect links to specific VPCs via Cloud Router.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: VLAN attachments (InterconnectAttachments) connect your Cloud Interconnect connection to a Cloud Router in a specific VPC network. Multiple VLAN attachments can use a single Interconnect connection to connect different VPCs or projects.

ul.li: Each VLAN attachment has a unique VLAN ID and connects to one Cloud Router.
BGP sessions are established between Cloud Router and on-premises router per attachment.
Attachments can be in different projects using Shared VPC or cross-project configurations.

question.title: Private Service Connect
question.scenario: You want to access Google APIs and third-party services using private IP addresses without sending traffic over the internet.
question.question-text: What feature provides private connectivity to Google and third-party services using internal IPs?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Private Service Connect provides private endpoints for services in your VPC.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Private Service Connect allows you to create private endpoints in your VPC that provide connectivity to Google APIs, Google-managed services, and third-party services. Traffic uses internal IP addresses and stays within Google's network.

ul.li: Endpoints are internal IP addresses in your VPC subnets.
Supports connecting to published services from service producers.
Enables private access from on-premises via VPN or Interconnect.

question.title: Firewall Logs
question.scenario: You need to troubleshoot connectivity issues and want to see which firewall rules are allowing or blocking traffic.
question.question-text: What feature provides visibility into firewall rule actions on network traffic?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Firewall Rules Logging shows which rules allowed or denied connections.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Firewall Rules Logging records connections that were allowed or denied by firewall rules. Each log entry shows the rule that matched, source/destination IPs, ports, protocol, and whether traffic was allowed or denied.

ul.li: Logging is enabled per firewall rule and can impact costs.
Logs are sent to Cloud Logging for analysis and alerting.
VPC Flow Logs capture all traffic metadata; Firewall logs show rule actions.

question.title: VPC Flow Logs
question.scenario: Your security team needs to monitor network traffic patterns and detect anomalies across your VPC.
question.question-text: What feature captures metadata about IP traffic flowing through VPC network interfaces?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: VPC Flow Logs capture network flow metadata for analysis.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: VPC Flow Logs capture metadata about IP traffic (source/destination IPs, ports, bytes, packets) going to and from VM network interfaces. They're useful for network monitoring, forensics, and traffic analysis. Flow Logs are enabled at the subnet level.

ul.li: Sampling rate and aggregation interval are configurable to balance cost and detail.
Logs include GKE pod information when applicable.
Integrates with BigQuery and third-party SIEM tools for analysis.

question.title: Session Affinity
question.scenario: Your application stores session data locally on web servers and requires users to return to the same backend instance.
question.question-text: What load balancer feature ensures requests from the same client are sent to the same backend?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Session affinity binds clients to specific backends.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Session affinity (sticky sessions) ensures that requests from the same client are directed to the same backend instance. Options include client IP affinity, generated cookie affinity, and header/cookie-based affinity for Application Load Balancer.

ul.li: Client IP affinity uses source IP to select backend.
Generated cookie affinity uses a load balancer-generated cookie.
Best practice is stateless backends, but affinity helps with legacy apps.

question.title: Packet Mirroring
question.scenario: Your security team needs to capture and analyze full packet payloads for intrusion detection without impacting production traffic.
question.question-text: What feature allows you to copy network traffic to a collector for analysis?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Packet Mirroring copies full packets to a collector for deep inspection.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Packet Mirroring clones traffic from specified sources (VMs, subnets, or network tags) and sends copies to a collector (internal load balancer fronting analysis tools). Unlike Flow Logs, it captures full packet contents for deep packet inspection.

ul.li: Supports filtering by protocol, IP ranges, and direction.
Collector can be IDS/IPS appliances, packet analyzers, or SIEM tools.
Mirroring doesn't affect source traffic performance or latency.

question.title: Direct Peering vs Cloud Interconnect
question.scenario: You need to access Google Workspace and YouTube with lower latency but don't need private connectivity to your VPC.
question.question-text: Which connectivity option provides direct access to Google's public services without private VPC access?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Direct Peering provides paths to Google's public services, not VPC access.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Direct Peering establishes a direct peering connection between your network and Google's edge network at peering locations. It provides access to Google's public services (Google Workspace, YouTube, etc.) but not private access to your GCP VPC resources.

ul.li: Direct Peering is free but has no SLA.
Requires meeting Google's peering requirements.
Carrier Peering is available through ISPs if you can't peer directly.

question.title: Global vs Regional Load Balancing
question.scenario: You are deploying an application that will only serve users in a single geographic region and want the most cost-effective load balancing option.
question.question-text: When should you choose a regional load balancer instead of a global load balancer?

choices.choice: When traffic is localized to one region and you want lower costs
When you need anycast IP addresses
When you need content-based routing globally
When you need automatic multi-region failover

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Regional load balancers are more cost-effective for single-region deployments.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Regional load balancers are appropriate when your backends are in a single region and your users are geographically close. They have lower costs than global load balancers and are suitable for internal applications or regionally-focused services.

ul.li: Regional external Application LB uses Standard network tier (lower cost).
Global external Application LB uses Premium tier with anycast IPs.
Internal load balancers are always regional.

question.title: DNS Peering
question.scenario: You have a Shared VPC setup and want service projects to use DNS zones defined in the host project.
question.question-text: What Cloud DNS feature allows one VPC to use private DNS zones from another VPC?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: DNS peering allows cross-VPC private DNS resolution.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: DNS peering zones allow a VPC network to forward DNS queries for specific domains to another VPC network that hosts the authoritative private zone. This enables centralized DNS management in Shared VPC or multi-VPC architectures.

ul.li: The producer VPC hosts the private zone; consumer VPCs create peering zones.
DNS peering is transitive: queries follow the peering chain.
Requires appropriate IAM permissions on the target zone.

question.title: Cloud IDS
question.scenario: You need managed network-based threat detection that integrates with your existing security tools.
question.question-text: What Google Cloud service provides managed intrusion detection for network threats?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud IDS provides managed intrusion detection using Palo Alto Networks technology.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud IDS is a managed intrusion detection service that analyzes mirrored traffic for threats. It uses Palo Alto Networks threat detection technology to identify malware, spyware, command-and-control attacks, and other network-based threats.

ul.li: Cloud IDS uses Packet Mirroring to analyze traffic without inline inspection.
Integrates with Security Command Center, SIEM, and SOAR tools.
Provides threat intelligence from Palo Alto Networks Unit 42.

question.title: Network Connectivity Center
question.scenario: You have multiple branch offices connected via VPN and want to enable branch-to-branch communication through Google's network.
question.question-text: What service provides hub-and-spoke connectivity for hybrid and multi-cloud networks?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Network Connectivity Center is a hub for managing hybrid connectivity.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Network Connectivity Center is a hub-and-spoke model for network connectivity management. It enables site-to-site data transfer through Google's network, connecting VPN tunnels, Interconnect attachments, and router appliances in a unified topology.

ul.li: Spokes can be HA VPN tunnels, Interconnect attachments, or SD-WAN appliances.
Enables any-to-any connectivity between connected sites.
Supports data transfer between on-premises locations via Google backbone.

question.title: Connection Draining
question.scenario: You need to remove a backend instance from the load balancer pool for maintenance without abruptly terminating active user sessions.
question.question-text: What feature allows existing connections to complete before removing a backend from service?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Connection draining gives existing connections time to complete gracefully.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Connection draining allows existing connections to a backend to complete gracefully when the backend is removed from the pool (due to scaling down, updates, or manual removal). New connections are not sent to the draining backend, but existing ones continue until timeout.

ul.li: Draining timeout is configurable (default 300 seconds, max 3600).
Works with MIG rolling updates for zero-downtime deployments.
Essential for stateful applications and long-running connections.

term.name: Virtual Private Cloud (VPC)
term.definition: A global, private, isolated virtual network in Google Cloud that provides networking functionality for your resources.
term.exam-note: VPCs are global; subnets are regional. Resources in the same VPC can communicate via internal IPs.

term.name: Subnet
term.definition: A regional resource that defines an IP address range within a VPC network from which VM instances receive their internal IP addresses.
term.exam-note: Subnets are regional and must have non-overlapping IP ranges within a VPC.

term.name: VPC Firewall Rule
term.definition: A rule that allows or denies traffic to/from VM instances based on configuration including direction, priority, targets, sources, and protocols.
term.exam-note: Ingress is denied by default; egress is allowed by default. Lower priority number means higher precedence.

term.name: Cloud NAT
term.definition: A managed network address translation service that enables instances without external IPs to access the internet for outbound connections.
term.exam-note: Cloud NAT is software-defined, highly available, and configured on Cloud Router.

term.name: Cloud VPN
term.definition: A service that provides encrypted IPsec VPN tunnels between your on-premises network and Google Cloud VPC over the public internet.
term.exam-note: HA VPN provides 99.99% SLA with two tunnels; requires dynamic routing with Cloud Router.

term.name: Cloud Interconnect
term.definition: A service that provides dedicated, private connectivity between on-premises networks and Google Cloud, bypassing the public internet.
term.exam-note: Dedicated Interconnect requires colocation; Partner Interconnect uses a service provider.

term.name: Cloud Router
term.definition: A fully distributed, software-defined router that uses BGP to dynamically exchange routes between your VPC and connected networks.
term.exam-note: Required for HA VPN and dynamic routing with Cloud Interconnect.

term.name: Cloud Load Balancing
term.definition: A suite of load balancing services that distribute traffic across backend resources based on type (global/regional, external/internal, protocol).
term.exam-note: Global Application LB for HTTP(S); Network LB for TCP/UDP; Internal LB for private traffic.

term.name: Cloud DNS
term.definition: A high-performance, resilient, global Domain Name System (DNS) service that publishes domain names to the global DNS.
term.exam-note: Supports public zones (internet), private zones (VPC only), and forwarding zones (hybrid).

term.name: Cloud CDN
term.definition: A content delivery network that caches HTTP(S) content at Google's globally distributed edge points of presence.
term.exam-note: Integrates with Global Application Load Balancer; supports cache invalidation and signed URLs.

term.name: Cloud Armor
term.definition: A DDoS protection and Web Application Firewall (WAF) service that protects applications behind Global Application Load Balancer.
term.exam-note: Security policies contain prioritized rules for allow, deny, throttle, or redirect actions.

term.name: Private Google Access
term.definition: A subnet-level setting that allows VMs without external IP addresses to reach Google APIs and services using internal IPs.
term.exam-note: Enable on subnets where VMs need Google API access without external IPs.

term.name: VPC Network Peering
term.definition: A feature that connects two VPC networks for internal IP communication, whether in the same project or different projects/organizations.
term.exam-note: Peering is non-transitive and requires non-overlapping IP ranges.

term.name: Shared VPC
term.definition: A feature that allows multiple projects (service projects) to use a common VPC network hosted in a host project.
term.exam-note: Centralizes network management while allowing distributed resource deployment.

term.name: Identity-Aware Proxy (IAP)
term.definition: A service that controls access to applications based on user identity and context rather than network location.
term.exam-note: Enables BeyondCorp zero-trust access without VPN; supports TCP forwarding for SSH/RDP.
